div.head: 20.5.1885 Mittwoch
div.p: Gee has been very, very ill so that the doctors had almost given her up but according to a letter from Papa to aunt Lulu she is a little better and has again eaten a little milk and bread without vomiting it. It has again given me a little hope. I am almost well again, Papas tongue is still bad Mamma very exhausted. If only my darling Gee could get better. Poor little thing she has such dreadful pain Mamma writes, such terrific headaches, she lies away complaining. And she is already so exhausted by the measles. Poor little thing, what a cross she has to bear. The ice has constantly to be changed. I start every time the bell goes for fear of a telegramm or a letter with bad news. Whenever I see aunt Lulu coming it frightens me for fear that something dreadful has happened. How thankful I shall be when, please God, my dear, dear little sister really begins to get better again. I never till now thought one could expect a letter so longingly and yet with such trembling as I do. Everything that happens seems an omen for good or bad. This incertainty is really dreadful. I really tremble ever to be without a book or something to occupy me for fear of the dreadful, dreadful thoughts that arise. Oh how fervently I pray that all may end well; and yet I always feel a kind of oppressing, uncomfortable uncertain feeling, even when reading or working. Everything I read palls upon me and yet I cannot be without a book, I wish for company and when I have it I do not like to talk. Yet how small is my burden compared to that of poor Mamma and Papa and my poor, poor dear little Gee. I do not wonder Mamma can only keep up with Quinine. It is a regular relief to be able to put on paper, what one can tell nobody, write to noone.
